stem: The nurse in a primary care clinic is reviewing the health maintenance schedules for four adult clients. Based on the client's current age and documented history in the EHR, match each client with the most appropriate priority screening intervention.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient 1: Ms. Davis (21-year-old female) presents for her first wellness visit since turning 21. She is sexually active and has never had a cervical screening.
Patient 2: Mr. Miller (46-year-old male) presents for a physical. He reports no current symptoms. He notes his father was recently diagnosed with a colon polyp.
Patient 3: Ms. Thompson (50-year-old female) reports she hasn't had any 'cancer tests' in several years. She has a mother who had breast cancer at age 65.
Patient 4: Mr. Harris (66-year-old male) is a former smoker (1 pack per day for 25 years). He quit smoking 3 years ago.

tabs.title: Historical Records
tabs.content:
Ms. Davis: No prior pelvic exams.
Mr. Miller: No prior colonoscopies.
Ms. Thompson: Last mammogram 6 years ago.
Mr. Harris: No prior abdominal ultrasounds.

rows.text: Ms. Davis (21 years old, sexually active)
Mr. Miller (46 years old, average risk)
Ms. Thompson (50 years old, average risk)
Mr. Harris (66 years old, former smoker)

rationale.correct: Cervical cancer screening (Pap test) starts at age 21 regardless of sexual history (r1). Colonoscopy screening for average-risk adults now starts at age 45 (r2). Mammography is recommended biennially (or annually depending on provider) for women starting at age 40 or 50 (r3). A one-time AAA screening with ultrasound is recommended for men aged 65 to 75 who have ever smoked (r4).
clinicalPearls: The 'Colonoscopy at 45' rule is a frequent NCLEX update.
AAA screening is specifically for men with a history of smoking.
At age 21, only the Pap test (cytology) is recommended; co-testing with HPV generally starts at age 30.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that a 46-year-old is 'too young' for a colonoscopy.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that the recommended age for colonoscopy screening was lowered from 50 to 45 due to rising rates of early-onset colorectal cancer.
